title: Section C
passagesOne: Questions 46 to 50 are based on the following passage.

questionsOne.Statement: The market sales of toilet paper have decreased because _____.

Options.text: Britons have cut their spending on it
its prices have gone up over the years
its quality has seen marked improvement
Britons have developed the habit of saving

questionsOne.Statement: What does the author think of the tissue paper market in the UK?

Options.text: It will expand in time.
It will remain gloomy.
It will experience ups and downs.
It will recover as population grows.

questionsOne.Statement: What does Jack Duckett say about toilet paper?

Options.text: Special offers would promote its sales.
Consumers are loyal to certain brands.
Luxurious features add much to the price.
Consumers have a variety to choose from.

questionsOne.Statement: What do we learn about Britons concerning toilet paper?

Options.text: They are particular about the quality of toilet paper.
They emphasize the strength of toilet paper the most.
They prefer cheap toilet paper to recycled toilet paper.
They reject using toilet paper with unnecessary features.

questionsOne.Statement: What can we infer from the last paragraph?

Options.text: More and more Britons buy recycled toilet paper to protect the environment.
Toilet paper manufacturers are facing a great challenge in promoting its sales.
Toilet paper manufacturers compete with one another to improve product quality.
Environmental protection is not much of a concern when Britons buy toilet paper.

passagesTwo: Questions 51 to 55 are based on the following passage.

questionsTwo.Statement: What does Lindson-Hawley say about her mother?

Options.text: She quit smoking with her daughter's help.
She succeeded in quitting smoking abruptly.
She was also a researcher of tobacco and health.
She studied the smoking patterns of adult smokers.

questionsTwo.Statement: What kind of support did smokers receive to quit smoking in Lindson-Hawley's study?

Options.text: They were given physical training.
They were looked after by physicians.
They were encouraged by psychologists.
They were offered nicotine replacements.

questionsTwo.Statement: How does Dr. Gabriela Ferreira view the result of Lindson-Hawley's experiment?

Options.text: It is idealized.
It is unexpected.
It is encouraging.
It is misleading.

questionsTwo.Statement: The idea of “a marathon” （Line 2, Para. 5） illustrates the popular belief that quitting smoking_____.

Options.text: is something few can accomplish
needs some practice first
requires a lot of patience
is a challenge at the beginning

questionsTwo.Statement: What happens when people try to quit smoking gradually?

Options.text: They find it even more difficult.
They are simply unable to make it.
They show fewer withdrawal symptoms.
They feel much less pain in the process.
